chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Pregnant women
chapter.summary: Covers the management of pregnant women with suspected and confirmed parvovirus B19 infection, or those who have been in contact with a person with suspected or confirmed parvovirus B19 infection.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 13 years onwards (Female).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.fullItemName: Management of suspected infection in pregnancy
subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage suspected parvovirus B19 infection in pregnancy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If parvovirus B19 infection is suspected at any stage of pregnancy, be aware that the clinical features may be indistinguishable from rubella infection.

  • Assess the woman's:
    • Gestation of pregnancy and expected date of delivery.
    • Date of onset, clinical features, and type and distribution of any rash and associated illness.
    • Previous relevant history of infection, immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibody testing, and measles/rubella vaccination status (with dates/places).
    • Known contact with any person with a potentially infectious rash or illness (with dates of contact).
  • Contact the local virology, microbiology, or infectious diseases department immediately for further advice on laboratory investigations and monitoring to arrange. This should include:
    • Confirming the diagnosis of parvovirus B19 infection.
    • Checking for rubella infection at the same time, irrespective of the woman's previous testing or immunization status to rubella. See the CKS topic on Rubella for more information on laboratory tests to arrange and subsequent management.
  • Give advice on sources of information and support, such as the NHS patient information leaflets Slapped cheek syndrome.
  • Give advice on self-management strategies for symptom relief, including:
    • Getting rest and drinking adequate fluids.
    • Using simple analgesia, such as paracetamol, if needed and appropriate. See the CKS topics on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain for more prescribing information.
  • Advise the woman that:
    • It is not usually necessary to stay off work if symptoms are controlled, as the infection is no longer contagious by the time the rash or arthropathy develops.
    • If the woman has not been fully immunized against rubella or got a documented history of previous rubella infection, it may be sensible to avoid contact with other pregnant women while any rash is present, until her rubella status is known.
  • Contact the local virology, microbiology, or infectious diseases department for further advice if there is any uncertainty about recommendations on isolation of pregnant women with suspected infection.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Suspected infection at any stage of pregnancy
  • The recommendation on assessing a woman with suspected infection at any stage of pregnancy is extrapolated from expert opinion in the Public Health England (PHE) publication UK Standards for microbiology investigations. Investigation of pregnant women exposed to non-vesicular rash [PHE, 2015].
    • Although the risks of fetal loss and hydrops fetalis are highest if parvovirus B19 infection is contracted within the first 20 weeks of pregnancy, there remains a low theoretical risk of transmission and adverse fetal outcome after this gestation.
Assessment of the woman
  • The recommendations on how to assess a pregnant woman with suspected parvovirus B19 infection are based on expert opinion in the PHE publication Guidance on viral rash in pregnancy [HPA, 2011] and expert opinion in a review article on common skin conditions in children [Allmon, 2015].
    • The rash and clinical features of parvovirus B19 infection may be indistinguishable from rubella infection, so a pregnant woman with a rubella-like rash requires assessment for both infections.
Arranging laboratory investigations for parvovirus B19 and rubella infection
  • The recommendation to contact the local virology, microbiology, or infectious diseases department for specialist advice immediately is extrapolated from expert opinion in a review article on pregnant women exposed to childhood rash [MacMahon, 2012].
  • The recommendation to arrange investigations for rubella irrespective of the woman's previous antibody test results or immunization status is based on expert opinion in the PHE publication Guidance on viral rash in pregnancy, as there is a small chance of past laboratory or documentation error, failed antibody response to immunization, or symptomatic rubella re-infection [HPA, 2011].
Advice on self-management strategies
  • The recommendations on self-management strategies for symptom relief are extrapolated from expert opinion in a review article on parvovirus B19 infection and roseola infantum [O'Grady, 2014] and a review article on common skin conditions in childhood [Allmon, 2015].
Advice on exclusion from work and isolation from at-risk contacts
  • The recommendation on not needing to stay off work is extrapolated from expert opinion in the PHE publication Guidance on infection control in schools and other childcare settings [PHE, 2016].
    • In working adults, there is no need for exclusion from work, as by the time the rash has developed, the period of infectivity has passed.
  • The recommendation for women with uncertain rubella immunization status to avoid contact with other pregnant women is pragmatic, as it is difficult to clinically differentiate between parvovirus B19 and rubella infection, and both may have serious or life-threatening sequelae for the fetus (or more rarely, the mother).
Seeking specialist advice
  • The recommendation on seeking advice from the local virology, microbiology, or infectious diseases department if there is uncertainty about ongoing management is based on expert opinion in a review article on pregnant women exposed to childhood rash [MacMahon, 2012].

subChapters.fullItemName: Management of possible exposure in pregnancy
subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage possible exposure to parvovirus B19 infection in pregnancy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
For women who have had possible exposure to parvovirus B19 infection at any stage of pregnancy:

  • Assess whether, and when, there has been significant contact with any person with a potentially infectious rash or illness (before the onset of rash, if any).
    • Significant contact is defined as being in the same room for 15 minutes or more, or face-to-face contact with the person, within the previous 3 weeks.
    • Be aware that household (rather than occupational) exposure is the most important source of infection in pregnancy.
    • If the woman is known to be susceptible to rubella, contact for less than 15 minutes should also be considered as possible exposure. See the CKS topic on Rubella for more information on the criteria for immunity, and management of women who are susceptible to rubella.
  • Assess the woman's:
    • Gestation of pregnancy and expected date of delivery.
    • Previous relevant history of infection, immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibody testing, and measles/rubella vaccination status (with dates/places).
  • Contact the local virology, microbiology, or infectious diseases department immediately for further advice on laboratory investigations to arrange to check for asymptomatic parvovirus B19 (and rubella infection, unless there is previous documented laboratory evidence that the woman is rubella immune).
    • Blood should be tested as soon after contact as possible.
    • See the CKS topic on Rubella for more information on the criteria for immunity, and management of women who are susceptible to rubella.
  • Advise the woman to avoid contact with other pregnant women and people at risk of complications, until she is known to be uninfected, immune to infection, or no longer potentially infectious.
    • The infectious period is 7–10 days before the rash (if any) develops, until one day after the rash appears.
    • If there is any uncertainty on the recommendations on isolation from other at-risk people, contact the local virology, microbiology, or infectious diseases department for further advice.
  • If the woman develops symptoms of active infection or if infection is confirmed, see the sections on How should I manage suspected parvovirus B19 infection in pregnancy? and How should I manage confirmed parvovirus B19 infection in pregnancy? for more information on management.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Possible exposure at any stage of pregnancy
  • The recommendation on assessing a woman with possible exposure at any stage of pregnancy is based on expert opinion in the Public Health England (PHE) publication UK Standards for microbiology investigations. Investigation of pregnant women exposed to non-vesicular rash [PHE, 2015].
    • Although the risks of fetal loss and hydrops fetalis are highest if parvovirus B19 infection is contracted within the first 20 weeks of pregnancy, there remains a low theoretical risk of transmission and adverse fetal outcomes after this gestation.
Definition of significant contact
  • The information on what constitutes significant contact is based on expert opinion in the PHE publication Guidance on viral rash in pregnancy [HPA, 2011].
    • The definition is based on research on varicella (chickenpox) transmission. As varicella is significantly more infectious than parvovirus B19, this is likely to be a conservative definition. Determining contact with parvovirus B19 may be difficult, because exposure to the virus occurs before the development of rash or other symptoms, and about 20% of children and up to 50% of adults are asymptomatic.
  • The information that the greatest risk of transmission is from a household (rather than occupational) contact is based on expert opinion in the PHE publication Guidance on infection control in schools and other childcare settings [PHE, 2016].
Assessment of the woman
  • The recommendations on how to assess a pregnant woman with possible exposure to parvovirus B19 infection are extrapolated from expert opinion in the PHE publication Guidance on viral rash in pregnancy [HPA, 2011].
Arranging laboratory investigations for parvovirus B19 and rubella infection
  • The recommendation to contact the local virology, microbiology, or infectious diseases department for specialist advice immediately is based on expert opinion in a review article on pregnant women exposed to childhood rash [MacMahon, 2012].
    • Immediate investigation of a pregnant woman is important because maternal asymptomatic infection is at least as likely to infect the fetus and cause potential complications as symptomatic infection. In addition, if infection is identified early, specialist interventions may reduce the risk of adverse outcomes such as hydrops fetalis and fetal death [HPA, 2011; MacMahon, 2012]. Up to 70% of infected pregnant women will be asymptomatic [SOGC, 2014].
  • The recommendation to arrange investigations for rubella unless the woman is known to be immune is based on expert opinion in the PHE publication UK Standards for microbiology investigations. Investigation of pregnant women exposed to non-vesicular rash [PHE, 2015].
    • The rash and clinical features of parvovirus B19 infection may be indistinguishable from rubella infection, so a pregnant woman with a rubella-like rash requires assessment for both infections if she is non-immune. Rubella is however rare in the UK, and most women receive antenatal screening for rubella antibodies in the early stages of pregnancy.
Advice on measures to reduce the risk of transmission
  • The recommendation on avoiding contact with other pregnant women and at-risk groups is extrapolated from expert opinion in the PHE publication UK Standards for microbiology investigations. Investigation of pregnant women exposed to non-vesicular rash [PHE, 2015].
    • These people are at increased risk of developing serious or life-threatening complications from parvovirus B19 infection, and immunocompromised people may not present with typical symptoms [Slavov, 2011].
  • The information on the infectious period is based on expert opinion in the PHE publication UK Standards for microbiology investigations. Investigation of pregnant women exposed to non-vesicular rash [PHE, 2015] and a review article on pregnant women exposed to childhood rash [MacMahon, 2012].
  • The recommendation on seeking specialist advice if there is uncertainty regarding ongoing management is based on expert opinion in a review article on pregnant women exposed to childhood rash [MacMahon, 2012].

subChapters.fullItemName: Management of confirmed infection in pregnancy
subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage confirmed parvovirus B19 infection in pregnancy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If parvovirus B19 infection is confirmed in a pregnant woman following laboratory investigations:

  • Arrange urgent referral to a specialist in fetal medicine (to be seen within 4 weeks of the onset of symptoms or estimated time of seroconversion) for ongoing monitoring and management.
    • Advise the woman that transmission to the fetus is unlikely, and specialist fetal monitoring will be arranged. If fetal transmission occurs, there may be effective specialist treatment options available.
  • If rubella infection is confirmed, see the CKS topic on Rubella for more information on specialist management.
  • Arrange admission or referral for the woman if there are suspected acute complications in pregnancy:
    • Arrange an urgent full blood count and reticulocyte count (if not already done) or emergency admission for women with symptoms of severe or aplastic anaemia (such as breathlessness, lightheadedness, lethargy, or confusion), depending on clinical judgement.
      • If there is any uncertainty about appropriate management, seek specialist advice from a haematologist.
    • Arrange an emergency obstetric admission if there is suspected maternal pre-eclampsia-like syndrome.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Specialist obstetric monitoring and management
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Specialist fetal monitoring may include:
    • Serial fetal ultrasound scans and Doppler assessment to detect fetal anaemia, heart failure, and hydrops. Ultrasound scanning may start around 4 weeks after the onset of symptoms or estimated time of seroconversion.
      • Hydrops fetalis may present on ultrasound with the development of ascites and thickening and enlargement of the fetal heart.
  • If there is suspected fetal hydrops, options include:
    • Parvovirus B19 viral DNA detection in amniotic fluid.
    • Fetal blood sampling and intrauterine red blood cell transfusion, which may reduce the fetal mortality rate.

[Lamont, 2011; HPA, 2011; SOGC, 2014; UK National Screening Committee, 2014]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Arranging urgent referral to a specialist in fetal medicine
  • The recommendation on arranging urgent referral to a specialist fetal medicine unit is based on expert opinion in the Public Health England (PHE) publication Guidance on viral rash in pregnancy [HPA, 2011] and a review article on pregnant women exposed to childhood rash [MacMahon, 2012].
    • Specialist units will have resources to provide specialist counselling, serial fetal monitoring, and intervention if needed.
Arranging admission or referral if suspected complications
  • The recommendation on checking an urgent full blood count (including reticulocyte count) if severe or aplastic anaemia is suspected is extrapolated from expert opinion in a review article on parvovirus B19 infection and people with sickle cell disease and thalassaemia [Slavov, 2011].
    • Rarely, parvovirus B19 may cause anaemia in healthy people, or parvovirus B19-induced anaemia may be the first indication of an underlying haematological disorder.
  • The recommendation on seeking specialist advice from a haematologist if there is any uncertainty about management if anaemia or reticulocytosis is confirmed, is pragmatic based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
  • The recommendation on arranging emergency admission if there is suspected maternal pre-eclampsia-like syndrome is based on expert opinion in the Society of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists of Canada clinical practice guideline Investigation and management of non-immune fetal hydrops [Desilets, 2013], as this condition is potentially life-threatening to the mother.
